headline: Korean regulators approve Yancoal's Rio Tinto deal
text:
Chinese-dominated miner Yancoal has cleared another hurdle in its bid to acquire Rio Tinto's Hunter Valley coal assets, with the Korean Fair Trade Commission giving its blessings to the deal.

Korea's status as a large consumer of Hunter Valley thermal coal ensured the KFTC had a say over the $US2.45 billion ($3.3 billion) acquisition, which has been dubbed "Project Monkey King" within Yancoal and its Chinese major shareholder.

The Korean approval comes barely three weeks after Australia's Foreign Investment Review Board gave its blessing, but Yancoal still has a long list of approvals to obtain before the deal can go ahead.

Four different agencies within China are yet to give their clearance, including the National Development and Reform Commission (NDRC), the Ministry of Commerce as well as regulators from Shandong Province where Yancoal's ultimate parent Yankuang is based.
summary:
Chinese-dominated miner Yancoal has cleared another hurdle in its bid to acquire Rio Tinto's Hunter Valley coal assets, with the Korean Fair Trade Commission giving its blessings to the deal.
The Korean approval comes barely three weeks after Australia's Foreign Investment Review Board gave its blessing, but Yancoal still has a long list of approvals to obtain before the deal can go ahead.
Four different agencies within China are yet to give their clearance, including the National Development and Reform Commission (NDRC), the Ministry of Commerce as well as regulators from Shandong Province where Yancoal's ultimate parent Yankuang is based.
Korea's status as a large consumer of Hunter Valley thermal coal ensured the KFTC had a say over the $US2.45 billion ($3.3 billion) acquisition, which has been dubbed "Project Monkey King" within Yancoal and its Chinese major shareholder.
